#ã‚¬ã‚¿ã®æ¹¯ #æ–°æ½Ÿ #è“¬å¹³æ¸©æ³‰ #å’Œæ³‰å±‹ #é•·å²¡ #è²¸åˆ‡éœ²å¤©é¢¨å‘‚ #æ¸©æ³‰ #ç¾è‚Œã®æ¹¯ #æ—…è¡Œ #å®¶æ—æ—…è¡Œ #æ˜æ²»æ™‚ä»£

Hello everyone! This is â€œGata no Yuâ€ introducing the charms of Niigata's hot springs. This time, we would like to introduce you to Yomogihira Onsen, a historic hot spring resort that is the pride of Nagaoka City, Niigata Prefecture. Known as the backwater of Nagaoka City, this hot spring is a historic place that has been healing therapeutic bath visitors since the Meiji era.

It is only a little over an hour drive from Niigata City. After crossing a red bridge surrounded by lush green mountains, you will see Izumiya, which we will introduce here. This hot spring resort has welcomed many people from inside and outside of the prefecture with its hospitality that has remained unchanged since the Meiji era. Especially in winter, many visitors come for the snow-viewing baths. In this issue, we will tell you all about the charms of Izumiya!

Although Izumiya has a long history, it is also attractive for its excellent facilities that meet modern needs. One such room is Kaede, a special room in the south wing. What a spacious space that can be used by two families! It has a main room, a second room, and even a Western-style room, and can accommodate up to 8 people. It is perfect for not only a family trip but also a trip for three generations. With enough space for children to run around, it is truly a â€œspace for strengthening family ties.

The highlight of the stay, however, is the â€œYamanoâ€ private open-air bath! As the name suggests, the outdoor baths are surrounded by the natural beauty of the mountains, giving guests the feeling of being immersed in the great outdoors. The rock baths are in perfect harmony with the surrounding scenery and are truly worthy of the name â€œYamano.

Particularly impressive at â€œYamanoâ€ is the tanuki (raccoon dog) sculpture by the bath. The tanuki, which looks as if it is worshipping something, adds to the atmosphere of the hot spring baths. It is as if the spirits of the mountain are watching over the guests.

Now, here is some good information for hot spring enthusiasts. Yomogihira Onsen is called â€œAlkaline Simple Sulfur Reiko Onsen,â€ a name that may make you bite your tongue. What is noteworthy is its sliminess. The water is thicker than normal hot water, and is truly worthy of being called â€œhot water for beautiful skin. It has been attracting many people with its beneficial effects since the Meiji era. It is a luxurious experience to have all the hot spring water for beautiful skin all to yourself at Yamano.

In addition to â€œYamano,â€ Izumiya has various other hot springs, such as â€œHoshi-no-yuâ€ and â€œTsuki-no-yu. Each has a different atmosphere and benefits, so it may be fun to visit different hot springs during your stay. You will feel as if you were a Touji guest in the Meiji era.

Finally, Izumiya also offers day-trip bathing, with four-hour courses available, so those who cannot stay overnight can still enjoy the charms of Yomogihira Onsen to the fullest.

Yomogihira Onsen is a hot spring located in the backcountry of Nagaoka. Its charms include traditions handed down from the Meiji era, spacious guest rooms, the luxurious private open-air bath â€œYamano,â€ and the alkaline hot springs that are known for their skin-beautifying properties. Forget the hustle and bustle of the city and spend a relaxing time in a historic hot spring resort. For such a luxurious time, why don't you come and visit us?

It is the largest festival in Shibata City that has been going on since the Edo period.
There will be a goldfish daiwa (a wheel), a yosakoi, a mikoshi shrine, a festival of shibatakko, a folk song play, a parade, etc. There are also many stalls, and it is crowded with many tourists.
One of the highlights of the festival is the gorgeous pedestal wheel that the six towns compete with. The flower of the festival "dairin" has been carefully handed down in the six towns for about 280 years, and the floats, dharma coats, and behaviors are each unique, making it one of the highlights. Among them, the "Return Wheel" is a festival in which men show their enthusiasm and enthusiasm and tow floats around the city, and the mood of the festival is suddenly enlivened, attracting many tourists every year.

Store Name
Arakawa Ramen Soul Ashira

Address
1217-6 Kirida, Murakami City, Niigata Prefecture

Phone number
0254-62-2291

Business hours
10:00-23:30ï¼ˆL.O 23:00)

Gata no Yu Ramen Edition! This is Nanami Otsuka from NGT48. This is Nanami Otsuka, a member of NGT48. Please watch the results of my food reportage trained at Lagoon Chubu!

As you know, I love ramen, but I always order the same thing. This time, however, I decided to take the plunge and try a menu item that I would never normally choose: Arakawa Ramen Tamashira Honten, located about 20 minutes by car from Takanosu Onsen in Sekikawa-mura, Niigata Prefecture. The ramen here is really delicious! There is another store in Bandai City, and I usually go for the miso ramen without hesitation, but today...what a challenge to try the tantanmen! When I looked at the menu, I was attracted by the words â€œhandmade tantanmen with plenty of sesameâ€. I was kind of tempted to try it.

Well, here it comes! The tantanmen is here! The first thing that surprised me was the appearance. It was not at all reddish in color as I had imagined. However, the aroma of sesame is so strong that it is enough to make my stomach growl.... Now, it's time to try it!

This is so delicious...!

I couldn't help but let out an audible gasp. The soup is very mild, yet rich. The spiciness comes later, but it is very tasty! And the spicy sansho (Japanese pepper) was so tangy, it was almost addictive.

The dumplings I ordered with it were also excellent! They were big and juicy, with sticky skin but crispy outside.
I recommend dipping them in vinegar and pepper! Isn't this kind of mature? (LOL).

The usual miso ramen is delicious, but I am so glad I tried this new menu item. The thickening and numbing spiciness of this tantanmen and the sticky texture of the gyoza. I can't wait to try it again. It might be a good idea for you to try a new menu item once in a while. You may discover something unexpected!

#æ—¥æœ¬é…’ #ã‚ã¹ #ãƒãƒ¼ã‚ºã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚­ #æ–°æ½Ÿ #ã‚ã‚“ã“ã† #é§…å‰ #é€šé¢¨é‹ #ãƒã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒãƒ¼ã‚ºã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚­ #éš ã‚Œå®¶ #ç™½å­ #ç‰¡è £

â€œSAKE Koi Japanâ€ is a hideaway sake bar in front of Niigata Station, where we enjoyed rare sake that made us do a double-take and the cheesecake that has been the talk of the town! Actually, the store has a mysterious sign saying â€œWe are not a cake shop...â€. What on earth does it mean? And what is the identity of the sake that looks just like calpis? Let us introduce you to SAKE Koi Japan, where you can enjoy Niigata's nightlife at its best!

Hello, I am Nanami Otsuka, aka Nanamin, director of Buzz Times! This time, I have sneaked into â€œSAKE Love JAPAN,â€ a sake bar located in front of Niigata Station. Actually, this store is popular for its cheesecake, which is a hot topic on SNS. However, there is a sign at the entrance that says, â€œWe are not a cake shop. What does it mean? It makes you wonder, doesn't it?

Once inside the store, you will find a casual and stylish atmosphere. Although it mainly sells sake, it is a space that is distinctly different from the conventional image of an izakaya (Japanese style bar). When I spoke with the manager, Mr. Otsuka (who shares the same surname as mine!) He told me, â€œWe wanted to dispel the rigid image of sake, so we created a casual atmosphere.

Let's start with the food. The restaurant's recommendation is the â€œTsufu Nabe. It is a very luxurious nabe that includes anglerfish, oysters, and cod roe. All things that are not good for the gout, but this is a superb dish! The soup, made with homemade miso, has a deep flavor combined with the broth from the oysters. Each ingredient is so rich that you can't help but exclaim, â€œYum! I couldn't help but exclaim, â€œYum!

And don't forget the sake. First, we were served â€œAbe,â€ a new sake from the Abe Sake Brewery in Kashiwazaki. The sweetness spreads at first and the aftertaste is refreshing. Even those who do not like sake can easily drink this one.

Now for the cheesecake that is so famous. This time, we were served sweet potato basque cheesecake. The cheesecake is made from Silk Sweet sweet potatoes produced in Niigata Prefecture and is low in sugar to bring out the sweetness of the original sweet potato. The smooth texture and the natural sweetness of the sweet potato are exquisite. Here is a secret story about the cheesecake. In fact, the cheesecake was so popular that many people mistakenly thought, â€œIs this a cake shop?â€ The cheesecake was so popular that many people mistakenly thought it was a cake shop. That is why the sign at the entrance was created. The manager, Mr. Otsuka, says, â€œI want people to enjoy everything, including the food. Certainly, the nabe and sake were excellent, too.

After leaving the restaurant, we took a short walk around Niigata Station. The area around the recently renovated station is getting a lot of attention for being â€œTokyo-like. When I actually walked around the area, I found that it does indeed have an urban atmosphere. But it is unmistakably Niigata. SAKE Koi Japan is a wonderful place where you can fully enjoy the charm of Niigata's ingredients and sake. Not only the cheesecake, but also the food and sake are superb. If you are ever in Niigata Station, be sure to stop by. But please do not ask, â€œIs this a cake shop? (laugh). Niigata's nightlife is still full of charm. What will you discover next? We will continue to introduce you to Niigata's hidden gems and ways to enjoy them, so please look forward to it!

#Sake #Abe #Cheesecake #Niigata #Ankou #Ekimae #Tongfu Nabe #Basque Cheesecake #Hideaway #Milfoil #Oysters

#ä¸Šè¶Šæ•™è‚²å¤§å­¦ #æ•™å“¡ #å…ˆç”Ÿ #æ•™è‚² #å°±è· #æ•™å“¡å°±è·ç‡ #æ•™è‚²å®Ÿç¿’ #æ–°æ½Ÿ #å›½ç«‹ #æ•™å¸« #å¤¢
Hello everyone! I am Moe Sugimoto, Buzz Times Director. This time, I visited Joetsu University of Education, which has one of the highest teacher employment rates in Japan.

We spoke with current students and Vice President Ueno to find out what makes this university so appealing. Students were attracted by the catchphrase â€œa university for those who definitely want to become teachers,â€ and highly valued the environment where they can engage in friendly competition with like-minded students. What was particularly impressive was the fact that many students aim to become teachers in their hometown of Niigata Prefecture.

A unique initiative of Joetsu University of Education is the â€œNiigata Next Generation Teacher Training Program. This innovative program, which begins in the second year of high school, allows students to learn about the work of teachers on a hands-on basis. I heard from graduate students that the program offers practical experiences such as fieldwork on Sado Island and visits to schools on remote islands.

Also impressive was the mascot character â€œJokyo-sensei,â€ whose motif is based on the university's school building.

This university is more than just a place to train teachers; it is a place to nurture a passion for education and a love for the community. It is hoped that through the Niigata Next Generation Teacher Training Program, more outstanding teachers will become active in Niigata Prefecture.

If you aspire to become a teacher or are interested in education, please check out Joetsu University of Education's open campus and the Niigata Next Generation Teacher Training Program. You are sure to discover something new!

#å’æ¥­æ—…è¡Œ #æ¸©æ³‰æ—…è¡Œ #éœ²å¤©é¢¨å‘‚ #å¤§æ±Ÿæˆ¸æ¸©æ³‰ç‰©èª #ç‰‡å±±æ´¥æ¸©æ³‰ #çŸ³å·çœŒ #æ–°æ½ŸçœŒ #åŠ è³€ #ãƒã‚¤ã‚­ãƒ³ã‚° #æ¸©æ³‰ã‚½ãƒ ãƒªã‚¨ #ãƒ›ãƒ†ãƒ« #ã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ‰ãƒ«ã€€#å¤§æ±Ÿæˆ¸æ¸©æ³‰ç‰©èª

We closely follow Haruka Ogoshi, who is graduating from NGT48, on her special graduation trip! The destination chosen was â€œOedo Onsen Monogatari Premium Kaga Maruyaâ€ in Katayamazu Onsen, Ishikawa Prefecture. Together with fellow group member and onsen sommelier Nanami Otsuka, they will embark on a trip to create the best memories at this newly renovated wonder hotel.

When they arrived at the hotel, they were greeted by round designs scattered everywhere. Mr. Ogoshi was immediately intrigued by the interior design, which, as the name suggests, is typical of a â€œMaruyaâ€ hotel. He began to speculate, â€œIs it round because it's a Maruya? The solution to the mystery surrounding the â€œcircleâ€ became a fun topic of conversation during the graduation trip.

Ms. Goto, a front desk staff member, tells us about the five new points added with the reopening on November 1. All-you-can-drink at the premium lounge, a buffet featuring local menus, â€œtotoi-okoroâ€ for after bathing, extensive entertainment facilities, and Japanese bed-type guest rooms. Their eyes light up when they see the luxurious facilities, which are perfect for celebrating Mr. Ogoshi's graduation.

The room they were shown was like an exploration. After passing through the Japanese-style room, they were surprised to see a bedroom that suddenly appeared. It's the perfect adult space for a graduation trip! He was so excited.

Finally, it was time to experience the hot springs. Mr. Otsuka, a hot spring sommelier, explained the characteristics of Katayamazu Onsen to Mr. Ogoshi, who was impressed by the view of Shibayamigata from the open-air bath. The sodium, calcium, and chloride properties of the hot spring water are like a natural pack. The hot spring water does not easily cool down and has an excellent moisturizing effect,â€ she explained. Ms. Ogoshi was delighted.

After relaxing both body and soul in the hot spring, it was time for the buffet we had been looking forward to. Local and national specialties such as hot sirloin steak grilled in the live kitchen, â€œonsen seiro-mushi,â€ a steamed dish of nine different ingredients, Kanazawa oden, and Hakata motsunabe are all on the menu, as if to celebrate graduation. Of particular note is the mysteriously named â€œZuppa Ingleseâ€ dessert. The gentle sweetness of the dessert impressed Ms. Ogoshi, who said, â€œIt's a taste that will remain in my graduation memories! She was thrilled with the taste.

Toward the end of his trip, Mr. Ogoshi wonders about the square shape of Totoitokoro. Why is this hotel square when the theme of the hotel is â€œroundâ€? Mr. Goto cannot answer this mystery. However, Mr. Ogoshi's keen insight leads him to an unexpected conclusion.

In this video, through the special trip of Ms. Haruka Ogoshi, who is graduating from NGT48, you can enjoy the benefits of the hot springs, the appeal of the food, and the solution to the mystery of the â€œcircleâ€ and â€œsquareâ€ that are scattered throughout the hotel. Her lively dialogue with Nanami Otsuka, a member of the same group, is another highlight of the program.

This is a hot spring trip that closely follows an idol's graduation trip, and is full of laughter, surprises, and excitement. Ishikawa Prefecture's hidden hot springs and exquisite buffets are sure to tickle the traveler's fancy. Why not watch this video and make a special travel plan with your loved ones?

#ç€ç‰© #ãƒ‡ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ #å’Œæœ #ãŸã¡ã°ãª #æ–°æ½Ÿ #ã‚¹ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ« #æ—¥æœ¬æ–‡åŒ– #ãƒ•ã‚¡ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ #è¶£å‘³ #å’Œè£… #ä¼çµ± #NGT48 #ç¾äºº

 In this issue, Moe Sugimoto of NGT48 will tell you about the ancient Japanese tradition of â€œKimonoâ€ and how she was fascinated by its depth at Tachibana Apita Kameda. Do you think that kimonos are only worn on special occasions? In fact, it is now attracting attention as a fashionable everyday item!

Long-established kimono store boasts an amazing track record
Tachibana Apita Kameda has an amazing track record. The Tachibana Apita Kameda store has had an astonishing track record! This is no mere coincidence. This is the crystallization of the store's efforts to get close to each customer and carefully convey the charm of kimono to them.

This time, we were guided into the world of kimono by the store manager, Mr. Maruyama. Mr. Maruyama's warm smile and wealth of knowledge gradually relaxed Sugimoto's nervousness.

Japanese beauty born from a single piece of cloth
When it came to choosing a kimono, Maruyama suggested a beautiful kimono in light blue, Sugimoto's member color.

I asked myself, â€œIs this really going to be a kimono?â€ The kimono we chose was a piece of cloth (a scrap of cloth).
Sugimoto was skeptical, but with Maruyama's skillful hands, the cloth gradually took shape in front of his eyes. Starting from the collar, the process of folding and adjusting the cloth to fit the body was like magic.

In the process of dressing, I also realized how wonderful the 100% silk fabric is. The way it shines beautifully in the light is like a natural skin filter. No wonder it looks so good on the face.

The spirit of harmony that lives on in the modern age
The word â€œkimonoâ€ may conjure up an image of stuffiness. However, according to Ms. Maruyama, more and more people are enjoying wearing kimonos in their daily lives. Kimonos are being used in a variety of situations, such as visiting cafes with friends, going to reunions, and watching Kabuki.

What is even more surprising is the full range of services offered by Tachibana Apita Kameda, including a 10-year free care guarantee, outing parties in kimono, and kimono dressing classes, all of which are designed to make the kimono more accessible. I was particularly intrigued by the method of dressing a kimono easily with just three rubber belts. Even Sugimoto could try this!

Encountering a new you
There was a dignified Sugimoto there, a different person from her usual self. According to Ms. Maruyama, the most attractive thing about wearing a kimono is that it allows you to be a different person from your usual self. Indeed, I felt like I could discover a different side of myself by wearing a kimono.

Now, you too can make your kimono debut!
Through this experience, Moe Sugimoto became obsessed with the charm of kimono. Why don't you try stepping into the world of kimono? A new encounter with a new you is surely waiting for you.

At Tachibana Apita Kameda, we have an environment where even kimono beginners can consult with us with ease. They provide total support from kimono selection to dressing and even events for kimono enjoyment, so you should be able to eliminate any worries you may have about making your kimono debut.

Finally, there is one thing I felt through this experience. The kimono is not only a special costume that wears traditional Japanese culture, but also a wonderful tool to express our individuality in the modern age. Why don't you discover a new you in kimono?

#é‡‘æ›œæ—¥ #ã‚·ãƒ³ãƒ‡ãƒ¬ãƒ© #ãƒ›ãƒ†ãƒ« #æ°·çµ #é€±æœ« #å¤§äººã®æ™‚é–“ #ã²ã¨ã‚Šæ™‚é–“ #ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¬ã‚¹ç™ºæ•£ #éæ—¥å¸¸ #ã‹ã‚‰ã‚ã’ #ãƒãƒ†ã‚µãƒ© #ãƒ—ãƒè´…æ²¢ #é‡‘æ›œã‚·ãƒ³ãƒ‡ãƒ¬ãƒ©

It is Friday when the night falls. The hustle and bustle of the week dies down and a special time begins. On this once-a-month night, there is only one thing to look forward to. It is an irreplaceable time spent at the hotel after work.

The moment you leave the hustle and bustle of the city and open the door to your hotel room. There you will find a tranquil space cut off from everyday life. With just a few drinks and your favorite snacks, you feel the fatigue of the week slowly melt away.

My companion for this special night is â€œHyoketsu Unsweetened Lemon. I open the chilled can and start drinking with gusto. At 7% alcohol by volume, this drink is characterized by a clear lemon flavor with no extra sweetness. With the first sip, the clear taste spreads in your mouth and gradually transforms you from on to off.

The table is lined with some of our favorite snacks prepared for the evening. Crispy fried tofu and smooth potato salad. The simple flavors are enhanced when paired with a glass of ice-cold unsweetened lemon.

In the quiet room, the quest for taste begins like a solitary gourmet. A classic attempt to add a little mayonnaise to karaage. The mildness of the mayonnaise accentuates the richness of the karaage and blends with the freshness of the Hyoketsu unsweetened lemon to create a new flavor. Next, add a tiny amount of pepper to the potato salad. The added tangy stimulation makes the lemon flavor more vivid.

As you enjoy these changes in flavor, you will gradually feel your mind being released. Daily stress and tension seem to melt away with each sip. Because it is an extraordinary space, small pleasures and discoveries that you would not normally notice will lighten your heart.

As night falls, Hyoketsu Unsweetened Lemon creates a time for quiet reflection. We reflect on the week, celebrate small successes, and quietly build anticipation for the new week ahead. This is an important time to reflect with yourself and build up your energy for tomorrow.

At this late hour of the night, why not find your own special way to spend your Friday? A time to relax quietly with a few drinks in your hand. There, you may find a little luxury that you cannot experience in everyday life and a new encounter with a new you.

See you next time, and good night.

#Friday #Cinderella #Hotel #Hyoketsu #Weekend #adult time #alone time #stress relieving #extraordinary #karaage #potesara #petit luxury #Friday Cinderella

The scenery of singing and dancing in the city to the folk song "Niitsu Matsuzaka", which has become a well-established summer event in Niitsu, is the color of summer in Echigo. The folk song "Niitsu Matsuzaka" is known all over the country, but it is during this summer festival that Niitsu Matsuzaka is danced and flowed.
In addition, at the "Yatai Festival", gorgeous stalls run around and violently collide with each other.
Every year from August 19 to 21, various Shinto rituals and events are held mainly in the former Niitsu City, and it has become a source of inspiration for the local people.

The Iwafune Festival (Iwafune Taisai) is a traditional Japanese festival held annually in the port town of Iwafune, located in Niigata Prefecture. This vibrant celebration, which dates back to the Edo period (1603-1867), typically takes place in mid-October and spans two days.

The festival's centerpiece is the procession of nine ornate floats known as "oshagiri." Each float represents a different district of the town and is lavishly decorated with intricate carvings, gold leaf, and vibrant colors, reflecting the historical prosperity of Iwafune.

A unique aspect of the Iwafune Festival is the significant role played by children. They perform traditional music called "ohayashi" on the floats, a practice that has been passed down through generations, ensuring the continuity of local cultural heritage.

The festival revolves around the Iwafune Shrine, where various Shinto rituals are performed. One notable tradition is the "funadama" ritual, where boat-shaped ornaments are carried up the shrine's steps, symbolizing the town's deep connection to the sea.

#ç”Ÿå§œé†¤æ²¹ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ³ #é•·å²¡ #ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ #ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ³ #ã—ã‚‡ã†ãŒã®æµ· #ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ³ #ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¡ #ååº— #ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒƒã‚¯ãƒ©ãƒ¼ãƒ¡ãƒ³ #ã“ã ã‚ã‚Š #æ–°æ½Ÿã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¡


This time, NGT48's Nanami Otsuka visited a ramen restaurant in Nagaoka City called â€œShoga no Umi,â€ which, as the name suggests, is all about ginger. We tasted the quintessence of ginger soy sauce ramen, a Nagaoka staple, so please be sure to check it out until the end!

Sea of Ginger: https://www.instagram.com/shouganoumi/

As a member of NGT48, Nanami Otsuka continues to promote the charms of Niigata. This time, she takes on the challenge of trying Nagaoka's famous gourmet food. Shoga no Umi is a notable restaurant in Nagaoka that offers ginger soy sauce ramen with a unique character. We will get a closer look at its charms along with Ms. Otsuka's life-sized reaction.

Upon entering the restaurant, Mr. Otsuka was greeted by the strong aroma of ginger. Wow, what a smell! I was impressed by the look of surprise on her face. The ginger soy sauce ramen covered with a pile of chashu pork was brought to the table. The clear soup was filled with a strong aroma of ginger.

Finally, it was time to eat. When Ms. Otsuka took a sip of the soup, she said, â€œWow! The ginger is amazing! But it tastes so good! But it tastes so good! The soup is based on a crisp soy sauce flavor, with a strong spiciness from the ginger. However, it is not just spicy. It has a refreshing aftertaste, and Mr. Otsuka praised it as a perfect dish for the cold season.

The noodles are made of medium-thick noodles with a firm texture. The noodles intertwine perfectly with the soup and bring out the full flavor of the ginger. It's like you can smell the ginger from the noodles! I couldn't help but smile at Mr. Otsuka's surprised comment, â€œIt's like I can smell the ginger from the noodles!

The true essence of this ramen is the pork, which is placed on top of the ramen noodles in a heaping pile. At Shoga no Umi, they are particular about their chashu pork and season it differently depending on the part of the meat. Mr. Otsuka was impressed, â€œThe meat is so tender, it melts in your mouth! Mr. Otsuka was impressed. The look on Mr. Otsuka's face as he enjoyed a variety of flavors in one bowl, from sweet char siu pork to savory smoky flavors, was pure bliss.

Even more surprising was the fried rice ordered as part of the set. At only 160 yen, the price was unbeatable, and Otsuka-san was surprised to hear, â€œWhat? So much for 160 yen? Mr. Otsuka exclaimed in amazement, â€œ160 yen for so much! The fried rice is characterized by its parapara-meat texture and light flavor. This fried rice goes perfectly with the ginger soy sauce ramen.

The ginger soy sauce ramen at â€œShoga no Umiâ€ was a shock to Mr. Otsuka. I've never had ramen with so much ginger,â€ he said! But I'm going to get addicted to it! This video is a condensed version of Otsuka Shichikai's â€œGinger Soy Sauce Ramenâ€.

We recommend this dish not only for NGT48 fans, but also for ramen lovers. Why don't you enjoy the taste of Nagaoka with Mr. Otsuka?

Finally, I would like to visit â€œShoga no Umiâ€ after watching this video! If you think so, please let us know in the comments section. We look forward to hearing your thoughts and your reactions to Nanami Otsuka. See you in the next video!

#ginger soy sauce ramen #Nagaoka #chashu #chahan #ginger sea #ramen #gourmet #gourmet #famous restaurant #black ramen #obsession #Niigata gourmet

#ãŠå¹´ç‰  #è¡—é ­ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ #ãŠé‡‘ #é‡‘éŠ­æ„Ÿè¦š #NGT48 #å®¶æ— #ä¸–ä»£ #é‡‘é¡ #ä½¿ã„é“ #æ–°æ½Ÿ #ãŠé‡‘æŒã¡

å‡ºæ¼”è€…ï¼šNGT48æ‰æœ¬èŒã€€https://ngt48.jp/profile/detail/155


Otoshidama, a New Year's tradition cherished as a seasonal custom, might be one of the most anticipated moments of the year for children. But in reality, how much otoshidama do people actually receive? And how do they use this money?

This time, NGT48's Moe Sugimoto took to the streets to ask people of various ages about their "otoshidama situation." The results revealed surprising amounts and uses that far exceeded expectations, from shocking sums to amusing ways of spending that made us laugh!

First, the most shocking was the otoshidama episode of NGT48's Kairi Sato, who happened to pass by. Sato says, "I've been keeping all the otoshidama I've received since I was little, still in their original envelopes." Amazingly, she has kept 24 years' worth of otoshidama without spending it.

"Because it's 24 years' worth, it has become too weighty to easily spend on clothes or meals," Sato explains. When such an amount accumulates, it becomes difficult to use for everyday shopping. So, what does she plan to use it for? "Maybe as a down payment for a car," she answers, to which Sugimoto retorts, "But you don't even have a driver's license!" Sato's future dream seems to be either a "ski resort" or a "Mercedes-Benz," though the reasons weren't mentioned.

On the other hand, we also received interesting responses from those who give otoshidama. Particularly impressive were the grandmothers and grandfathers who give surprisingly large amounts to their grandchildren. "The unit is in tens of thousands of yen," one said, causing Sugimoto to exclaim in surprise.

One grandmother speaks about the amount of otoshidama, saying, "I just can't help but adore them," but at the same time mentions, "I try not to give too much for otoshidama, instead spreading my feelings to other occasions like birthdays." It seems she shows her love for her grandchildren on occasions other than New Year's as well.

Furthermore, an unexpected guest appeared in this interview. We were able to talk to the former governor of Niigata Prefecture, Mr. Hirayama. It turns out that Mr. Hirayama likes mystery novels and literature, and has a hobby of studying Mori Ogai's works. This episode gave us a glimpse of an unexpected side of someone who held such a high position.

Regarding how otoshidama is used, several responses were obtained. Some gave practical answers like "for living expenses," while others couldn't remember specific uses.

As we can see, the seemingly simple culture of otoshidama actually encapsulates various aspects of Japanese society. Through otoshidama, we can observe family relationships, economic concepts, education, and even changes in the times.

This interview highlighted diverse values towards otoshidama and unique customs in each family. Why don't you, our viewers, reflect on your own otoshidama experiences?

Now, dear viewers, what about your otoshidama situation? What was the highest amount you received? And what memories do you have? Please share your otoshidama episodes in the comments section.

And if you enjoyed this video, please subscribe to our channel and hit the like button!
